summary: Silvia Duran was an employee of the Cuban consulate in Mexico City in 1963. Her significance in the JFK assassination context stems from her interactions with Lee Harvey Oswald when he visited the consulate in September 1963 seeking a visa to travel to Cuba and potentially the Soviet Union. Documents detail a chronology of Oswald's visits and descriptions of his interactions with Duran. Following the assassination, Duran was interrogated by Mexican authorities about Oswald's visa application. A Cuban letter of protest to Mexico alleges Duran was mistreated during this interrogation and implicates the CIA in a conspiracy related to the Kennedy assassination, accusing Mexican police of complicity with those who planned Kennedy's assassination. The HSCA investigated the CIA's knowledge of Oswald and Duran in Mexico City.
significance: Silvia Duran's interactions with Lee Harvey Oswald at the Cuban consulate in Mexico City made her a person of interest in the investigation into the Kennedy assassination. Her role involves the processing of Oswald's visa application and subsequent interrogation, which led to allegations of CIA involvement and conspiracy theories surrounding the assassination.
